messages.subject: Re: Dr. Torigoye hako-gaki
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Ron, We had quite a decent write up on the NMB about the art names and seals he used. Instead of typing it all out (and there were quite a few pics) I would
messages.messageBody:
Hi Ron,

We had quite a decent write up on the NMB about the art names and
seals he used.
Instead of typing it all out (and there were quite a few pics) I would
refer you to the following link:
http://www.militaria.co.za/nmb/viewtopic.php?f=2&t=2462 or
http://tinyurl.com/34qyfu
Check out especially the second page..post by Paul (Myochin)
Hope this helps.

Regards,
Brian

--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Ron Hartmann" <swords@...> wrote:
>
> Looking at an old hako-gaki by he late Dr. Torigoye, he used two
seals; one seal is a square "name" seal and the other the round "has a
bird on it" seal. Does anyone remember when he used these two seals? I
seem to remember one being used in Japan, the other when writing
hako-gaki outside of Japan, but I'm unsure of that memory.
>
> I have a notation on the "square" sealed box, "Zaiya" and wonder if
that's a rating level of his.
>
> Thanks
>
> Ron
> STL
>

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Dr. Torigoye hako-gaki
messages.msgSnippet: ... Ron, As I recall, the round seal with the bird was used for hako-gaki written outside Japan. I also remember someone explaining the little marks on the
messages.messageBody:
On Thu, Mar 13, 2008 at 4:15 PM, Ron Hartmann <swords@...> wrote:

> Looking at an old hako-gaki by he late Dr. Torigoye, he used two seals;
> one seal is a square "name" seal and the other the round "has a bird on it"
> seal. Does anyone remember when he used these two seals? I seem to remember
> one being used in Japan, the other when writing hako-gaki outside of Japan,
> but I'm unsure of that memory.
>
> I have a notation on the "square" sealed box, "Zaiya" and wonder if that's
> a rating level of his.
>
> Thanks
>
> Ron
> STL
>
>


Ron,

As I recall, the round seal with the bird was used for hako-gaki written
outside Japan. I also remember someone explaining the little marks on the
right side of Dr. Torigoye's kao signifying his evaluation of quality or
value: one mark "1st class," 2 marks "2nd class."

Of course hako-gaki, like origami, are still just an opinion. I had a tsuba
with a hako-gaki by Dr. Torigoye attributing it to Dai-go-ro, with his "1st
class" notation on the kao. I sold it to someone who found it in a book
attributed to Akasaka, and the NBTHK gave it a paper as Akasaka.

So it goes.

Craig



--
Craig Harris
Books from and about Asia
www.bridgeofdreams.com

messages.subject: Dr. Torigoye hako-gaki
messages.msgSnippet: Looking at an old hako-gaki by he late Dr. Torigoye, he used two seals; one seal is a square name seal and the other the round has a bird on it seal. Does
messages.messageBody:
Looking at an old hako-gaki by he late Dr. Torigoye, he used two seals; one seal is a square "name" seal and the other the round "has a bird on it" seal. Does anyone remember when he used these two seals? I seem to remember one being used in Japan, the other when writing hako-gaki outside of Japan, but I'm unsure of that memory.

I have a notation on the "square" sealed box, "Zaiya" and wonder if that's a rating level of his.

Thanks

Ron
STL

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
